Old Crow Medicine Show  
---

on _A Prairie Home Companion_ in 2014

**Old Crow Medicine Show** is an [Americana](/wiki/Americana_\(music\)
"Americana \(music\)") [string band](/wiki/String_band "String band") based in
Nashville, Tennessee, that has been recording since 1998. They were inducted
into the [Grand Ole Opry](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry "Grand Ole Opry") on September
17, 2013.[2] Their ninth album,
_[Remedy](/wiki/Remedy_\(Old_Crow_Medicine_Show_album\) "Remedy \(Old Crow
Medicine Show album\)")_ , released in 2014, won the [Grammy Award for Best
Folk Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Folk_Album "Grammy Award for Best Folk
Album").[3] The group's music has been called [old-time](/wiki/Old-time_music
"Old-time music"), [folk](/wiki/Folk_music "Folk music"), and [alternative
country](/wiki/Alternative_country "Alternative country"). Along with original
songs, the band performs many pre-World War II [blues](/wiki/Blues "Blues")
and folk songs.

Bluegrass musician [Doc Watson](/wiki/Doc_Watson "Doc Watson") discovered the
band while its members were [busking](/wiki/Busking "Busking") outside a
pharmacy in [Boone, North Carolina](/wiki/Boone,_North_Carolina "Boone, North
Carolina"),[i 1] in 2000.[i 2] With an old-time string sound fueled by [punk
rock](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock") energy,[4][5] it has influenced acts like
[Mumford & Sons](/wiki/Mumford_%26_Sons "Mumford & Sons")[6][7] and
contributed to a revival of banjo-picking string bands playing Americana
music[7] — leading to variations on it.[5][8]

The group released their sixth studio album, _Volunteer_ , through [Columbia
Nashville](/wiki/Columbia_Nashville "Columbia Nashville") on April 20, 2018 —
coinciding with their 20th anniversary as a group. They released _[50 Years of
Blonde on Blonde](/wiki/50_Years_of_Blonde_on_Blonde "50 Years of Blonde on
Blonde")_ on April 28, 2017 (their first album on Columbia Nashville).[9]
Previous studio albums were _[O.C.M.S.](/wiki/O.C.M.S. "O.C.M.S.")_ (2004),
_[Big Iron World](/wiki/Big_Iron_World "Big Iron World")_ (2006), _[Tennessee
Pusher](/wiki/Tennessee_Pusher "Tennessee Pusher")_ (2008), _[Carry Me
Back](/wiki/Carry_Me_Back "Carry Me Back")_ (2012),[10] and
_[Remedy](/wiki/Remedy_\(Old_Crow_Medicine_Show_album\) "Remedy \(Old Crow
Medicine Show album\)")_ (2014).[11] Their song "[Wagon
Wheel](/wiki/Wagon_Wheel_\(song\) "Wagon Wheel \(song\)")", written by
frontman Ketch Secor through a co-authoring arrangement with [Bob
Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan"),[12] was certified
[platinum](/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification "Music recording sales
certification") by the [Recording Industry Association of
America](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America") in April 2013[13] and has been covered by a number of
acts, including [Darius Rucker](/wiki/Darius_Rucker "Darius Rucker"), who made
the song a [top 40](/wiki/Top_40 "Top 40") hit.[14]

The band was featured along with [Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic
Zeros](/wiki/Edward_Sharpe_and_the_Magnetic_Zeros "Edward Sharpe and the
Magnetic Zeros") and Mumford & Sons in the music documentary _[Big Easy
Express](/wiki/Edward_Sharpe_and_the_Magnetic_Zeros#Big_Easy_Express "Edward
Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros")_ , which won a [Grammy Award for Best Long
Form Music Video](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Long_Form_Music_Video "Grammy
Award for Best Long Form Music Video") in 2013.[w 1] They performed on the
Railroad Revival Tour across the U.S. in 2011.[15] They appeared at the
[Stagecoach Festival](/wiki/Stagecoach_Festival "Stagecoach Festival")
2013[16] and multiple times at other major festivals, e.g., [Bonnaroo Music
Festival](/wiki/Bonnaroo_Music_Festival "Bonnaroo Music Festival"),
[MerleFest](/wiki/MerleFest "MerleFest"),[w 2]:2000:2004:2008:2014 [Telluride
Bluegrass Festival](/wiki/Telluride_Bluegrass_Festival "Telluride Bluegrass
Festival"),[w 3] [Hardly Strictly Bluegrass
Festival](/wiki/Hardly_Strictly_Bluegrass_Festival "Hardly Strictly Bluegrass
Festival"),[w 4]:2004:2009 and [Newport Folk
Festival](/wiki/Newport_Folk_Festival "Newport Folk Festival").[l 1][l 2]

They have made frequent guest appearances on _[A Prairie Home
Companion](/wiki/A_Prairie_Home_Companion "A Prairie Home Companion")_ with
[Garrison Keillor](/wiki/Garrison_Keillor "Garrison Keillor"). The group
received the 2013 Trailblazer Award from the [Americana Music
Association](/wiki/Americana_Music_Association "Americana Music Association"),
performing at the [Americana Honors & Awards
Show](/wiki/Americana_Music_Honors_%26_Awards "Americana Music Honors &
Awards").[17]

Publishing administrator [Downtown Music
Publishing](/wiki/Downtown_Music_Publishing "Downtown Music Publishing")
represents the works of Old Crow Medicine Show.[18]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

###
Early[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Little_Grill_Collective.jpg/150px-
Little_Grill_Collective.jpg)](/wiki/File:Little_Grill_Collective.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Little_Grill_Collective.jpg "Enlarge")

Little Grill Collective in Harrisonburg, Virginia.

Ketch Secor and Critter Fuqua[10] first met in the seventh grade in
[Harrisonburg, Virginia](/wiki/Harrisonburg,_Virginia "Harrisonburg,
Virginia") and began playing music together.[7] They performed [open
mics](/wiki/Open_mic "Open mic") at the [Little Grill
diner](/wiki/Little_Grill_Collective "Little Grill Collective"),[12] as did
Robert St. Ours who went on to found [The Hackensaw
Boys](/wiki/The_Hackensaw_Boys "The Hackensaw Boys"). Secor's early influences
included "driving up to [Mt. Jackson, VA](/wiki/Mt._Jackson,_VA "Mt. Jackson,
VA") to the bluegrass Saturday night in the summer, going up to [Davis and
Elkins College](/wiki/Davis_and_Elkins_College "Davis and Elkins College") to
participate in the Old Time Music week there, and meeting guys like Richie
Stearns."[12] Secor formed the Route 11 Boys with St. Ours and his brothers,
and performed often at Little Grill.

[Willie Watson](/wiki/Willie_Watson_\(musician\) "Willie Watson \(musician\)")
first met Ben Gould in high school in [Watkins Glen, New
York](/wiki/Watkins_Glen,_New_York "Watkins Glen, New York") ([Schuyler
County](/wiki/Schuyler_County,_New_York "Schuyler County, New York")), and
began playing music together. Both Watson and Gould dropped out of school and
formed the band The Funnest Game.[n 2] Their brand of electric/[old-
time](/wiki/Old_time_music "Old time music") was heavily influenced by the
[old-time music](/wiki/Old_time_music "Old time music") scene prominent in
[Tompkins](/wiki/Tompkins_County "Tompkins County") and [Schuyler County, New
York](/wiki/Schuyler_County,_New_York "Schuyler County, New York"), including
[The Horse Flies](/wiki/The_Horse_Flies "The Horse Flies") and The Highwoods
Stringband.

### "Wagon
Wheel"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: "Wagon Wheel"")]

Main article: [Wagon Wheel (song)](/wiki/Wagon_Wheel_\(song\) "Wagon Wheel
\(song\)")

Fuqua, school friend and future bandmate, first brought home a [Bob
Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan") [bootleg](/wiki/Bootleg_recording "Bootleg
recording") from a family trip to [London](/wiki/London "London") containing a
rough outtake called "Rock Me, Mama" (from the "[Pat Garrett and Billy The
Kid](/wiki/Pat_Garrett_and_Billy_The_Kid "Pat Garrett and Billy The Kid")"
soundtrack sessions) and passed it to Secor.[i 3] Not "so much a song as a
sketch, crudely recorded featuring most prominently a stomping boot, the
candy-coated chorus and a mumbled verse that was hard to make out",[20] the
tune kept going through Secor's mind. A few months later, while attending
[Phillips Exeter Academy](/wiki/Phillips_Exeter_Academy "Phillips Exeter
Academy") in New Hampshire, and "feeling homesick for the South," he added
verses about "hitchhiking his way home full of romantic notions put in his
head by the [Beat poets](/wiki/Beat_poets "Beat poets") and, most of all,
Dylan." Dylan was a major influence on the young musician, as he puts it:

> I listened to Bob Dylan and nothing else. Nothin' but Bob for four years. It
> was like schooling. Every album and every outtake of every album and every
> live record I could get my hands on and every show I could go see live. I
> was a teenager who was really turned on to Bob.[20]

The Dylan outtake, generally titled "Rock Me Mama", came out of recording
sessions for the _[Pat Garrett and Billy the
Kid](/wiki/Pat_Garrett_%26_Billy_the_Kid_\(album\) "Pat Garrett & Billy the
Kid \(album\)")_ movie soundtrack (1973) in [Burbank,
California](/wiki/Burbank,_California "Burbank, California").[21][22] Secor
says it ". . was an outtake of something he had mumbled out on one of those
tapes. I sang it all around the country from about 17 to 26, before I ever
even thought, 'oh I better look into this.'"[12]

When Secor sought copyright on the song in 2003 to release it on
_[O.C.M.S.](/wiki/Old_Crow_Medicine_Show_\(album\) "Old Crow Medicine Show
\(album\)")_ in (2004), he discovered Dylan credited the phrase "Rock me,
mama" to [bluesman](/wiki/Blues "Blues") [Arthur "Big Boy"
Crudup](/wiki/Arthur_Crudup "Arthur Crudup"), who likely got it from a [Big
Bill Broonzy](/wiki/Big_Bill_Broonzy "Big Bill Broonzy") recording. As Secor
says: "In a way, it's taken something like 85 years to get completed."[23]
Secor and Dylan signed a co-writing agreement, and share copyright[w 5] on the
song; agreeing to a "50-50 split in authorship."[7]

Secor later met Dylan's son, Jakob, who said "it made sense that I was a
teenager when I did that, because no one in their 30s would have the guts to
try to write a Bob Dylan song."[23] The song would be an early entry in the
group's catalog when it formed a few years later. Officially released twice,
on an early EP and their second album ("O.C.M.S." in 2004), the song would
become the group's signature song—going gold in 2011 and platinum in 2013.[13]

### Upstate New York/Canada/North
Carolina[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Upstate New York/Canada/North Carolina")]

After the breakup of the Route 11 Boys, Secor attended [Ithaca
College](/wiki/Ithaca_College "Ithaca College").[1][19]:5 He brought Fuqua up
to New York State, where they met Willie Watson. Watson dissolved The Funnest
Game and they assembled players all around [Ithaca, New
York](/wiki/Ithaca,_New_York "Ithaca, New York") "where there is a very lively
old-time music scene",[n 3] including Kevin Hayes[19]:5 They recorded an album
that they could sell on the road—a cassette of ten songs called
_Trans:mission_. Fuqua says of the influence of that region . .

> Ithaca and that surrounding area was a big influence on us. We wouldn't be
> here without a lot of the people we met there, like Richie Stearns, the Red
> Hots and Mac Benford. All those old-time banjo players brought the music
> from the South back up to New York, and it was kind of a hotbed.[25]

The group left Ithaca for their _Trans:mission_ tour in October 1998. They
busked their way west across [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") and circled back
east again in the Spring of 1999 when they moved into a farmhouse on [Beech
Mountain](/wiki/Beech_Mountain_\(North_Carolina\) "Beech Mountain \(North
Carolina\)"), near [Boone, North Carolina](/wiki/Boone,_North_Carolina "Boone,
North Carolina"). They were embraced by the Appalachian community, and their
[repertoire](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/repertoire
"wikt:Special:Search/repertoire") of old-time songs grew as they played with
local musicians."[1]

### Busking
break[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Busking break")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Boone_Lights.jpg/175px-
Boone_Lights.jpg)](/wiki/File:Boone_Lights.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Boone_Lights.jpg "Enlarge")

Boone Drug (left) looking west down King Street, Boone, North Carolina; where
the group had their big busking break.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/DocW_Sculpture_Boone.jpg/225px-
DocW_Sculpture_Boone.jpg)](/wiki/File:DocW_Sculpture_Boone.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DocW_Sculpture_Boone.jpg "Enlarge")

Sculpture of Doc Watson at the corner King and Depot Streets in Boone, North
Carolina; he would invite Old Crow to perform at MerleFest after hearing them
at his "old corner".

One day the group were [busking](/wiki/Busking "Busking") outside a pharmacy
called Boone Drug—"playing on Doc's old corner" where he'd "started playing in
the 1950s" on King Street in [Boone, North
Carolina](/wiki/Boone,_North_Carolina "Boone, North Carolina")[i 1]—when the
daughter of folk-country legend [Doc Watson](/wiki/Doc_Watson "Doc Watson")
(d. May 29, 2012[26]) heard them.[n 4] Certain her father would be impressed,
she led the blind musician over for a listen. The group "struck up '[Oh My
Little Darling](/w/index.php?title=Oh_My_Little_Darling&action=edit&redlink=1
"Oh My Little Darling \(page does not exist\)")', a well-known old-time song
they thought Doc would like." When they finished, he said: "Boys, that was
some of the most authentic old-time music I've heard in a long while. You
almost got me crying."[1] Doc invited the band to participate in his annual
[MerleFest](/wiki/MerleFest "MerleFest") music festival[n 5] in [Wilkesboro,
North Carolina](/wiki/Wilkesboro,_North_Carolina "Wilkesboro, North
Carolina")[i 4] (for 2000).[w 2]:2000

To Secor: "That [gig](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/gig
"wikt:Special:Search/gig") changed our lives and we look to it as a pivotal
turning point as Old Crow Medicine Show.[i 5] He and Fuqua have written a song
"about Doc Watson. About being on the corner in Boone and him discovering us.
It honors Doc and the high country blues sound."[i 6]

Busking has "always been our heart and soul," claims Secor. "Our performance
comes out of all those years spent cutting our teeth on the street
corner."[28] The earliest beginnings of the group involved busking in the
Northeast U.S., attracting fresh talent. Guitjo player Kevin Hayes—originally
from [Haverhill, Massachusetts](/wiki/Haverhill,_Massachusetts "Haverhill,
Massachusetts")—was in [Bar Harbor, Maine](/wiki/Bar_Harbor,_Maine "Bar
Harbor, Maine") raking blueberries when he encountered Secor "on the street in
front of a jewelry store playing the banjo."[19]:5 Bassist Morgan Jahnig
joined the group[n 6] as a result of a "random" encounter with early Old Crow
performing on the streets of Nashville in 2000.[i 7] Guitarist Gill Landry
first met the group in 2000 while both were street performing during [Mardi
Gras](/wiki/Mardi_Gras_in_New_Orleans "Mardi Gras in New Orleans") in [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans"), joining full-time in 2007.[i 8]

To promote _Carry Me Back Home_ (2012), the group did a series of "guerilla"
shows around Nashville, including busking in front of the Ryman Auditorium
where they performed "Sewanee Mountain Catfight" for an "unsuspecting crowd of
tourists."[29]

### Grand Ole
Opry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Grand Ole Opry")]

The big busking break led to the act's relocation to
[Nashville](/wiki/Nashville "Nashville") in October 2000.[1][n 7] At
MerleFest, Secor explains, Sally Williams "from the [Grand Ole
Opry](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry "Grand Ole Opry") . . invited us to participate in
some summer music events at the [Grand Ole Opry
House](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry_House "Grand Ole Opry House") doing our street
act, our busking, and that's why we came to Nashville . ."[i 1] Williams first
booked them for "an Opryland Plaza outdoor show."[31] In Nashville they were
"embraced and mentored" by [Marty Stuart](/wiki/Marty_Stuart "Marty Stuart"),
the president of the Grand Ole Opry, who first spied the group at the
Nashville-area Uncle Dave Macon Days festival and added them to his "Electric
Barnyard old-fashioned country variety package show bus tour" with acts like
[Merle Haggard](/wiki/Merle_Haggard "Merle Haggard"), [Connie
Smith](/wiki/Connie_Smith "Connie Smith"), and [BR5-49](/wiki/BR5-49
"BR5-49"). Soon they were opening for "everyone from [Loretta
Lynn](/wiki/Loretta_Lynn "Loretta Lynn") and [Dolly Parton](/wiki/Dolly_Parton
"Dolly Parton") to [Ricky Skaggs](/wiki/Ricky_Skaggs "Ricky Skaggs") and [Del
McCoury](/wiki/Del_McCoury "Del McCoury") . ."[31]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Rymanauditorium1.jpg/175px-
Rymanauditorium1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rymanauditorium1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rymanauditorium1.jpg "Enlarge")

The Ryman Auditorium on 116 5th Avenue North in Nashville, Tennessee, known as
"The Mother Church of Country Music".

The group made their Grand Ole Opry debut at the [Ryman
Auditorium](/wiki/Ryman_Auditorium "Ryman Auditorium"), "The Mother Church of
Country Music", in January 2001. Given just four minutes on stage, they played
their original "Tear It Down"—a "singing jug-band romp about punishing
infidelity"[1]—and received a "rare first-time-out standing ovation, and a
call for an encore."[31] In August 2013, Stuart unexpectedly appeared onstage
at the [Ohio Theatre](/wiki/Ohio_Theatre_\(Cleveland,_Ohio\) "Ohio Theatre
\(Cleveland, Ohio\)") in [Cleveland](/wiki/Cleveland "Cleveland"), where the
group was performing, to invite them to become official members of the
Opry.[32] They were formally inducted at a special ceremony at the Grand Ole
Opry House in Nashville, September 17, 2013.[2]

###
Nettwerk[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Nettwerk")]

Shortly after their Opry debut, the group signed with Bobby Cudd at [Monterey
Peninsula
Artists](/w/index.php?title=Monterey_Peninsula_Artists&action=edit&redlink=1
"Monterey Peninsula Artists \(page does not exist\)"),[n 8] who also
represented [Robert Earl Keen](/wiki/Robert_Earl_Keen "Robert Earl Keen"), the
[Dave Matthews Band](/wiki/Dave_Matthews_Band "Dave Matthews Band"), [Chris
Isaak](/wiki/Chris_Isaak "Chris Isaak"), [Aerosmith](/wiki/Aerosmith
"Aerosmith"), and [Fiona Apple](/wiki/Fiona_Apple "Fiona Apple"). They went on
their "first real tour" May 2001, opening for the [Del
McCoury](/wiki/Del_McCoury "Del McCoury") band.[1] Appearances at the 2003
[South by Southwest](/wiki/South_by_Southwest "South by Southwest") (SXSW) in
Austin—a "scene" that's "all about getting behind young artists", as Secor
puts it—led to the group being signed by [Nettwerk](/wiki/Nettwerk
"Nettwerk"),[19]:2 securing their recording future for the next several years.
Their first Nettwerk offering, _Old Crow Medicine Show_ in 2004 (popularly
known as _[O.C.M.S.](/wiki/O.C.M.S. "O.C.M.S.")_), was produced by Dave
Rawlings and mixes "old blues and jug band music with originals that fit
smoothly into the tradition"—including the Fuqua "Take 'em Away"[n 9] and
Secor "Wagon Wheel".[n 10] More than 100,000 copies of O.C.M.S. were sold,
behind a "rigorous tour schedule and a memorable live show"; what CMT regarded
as "an impressive number for a new band that didn't know much about record
deals and everything that goes with it."[34]

_[Big Iron World](/wiki/Big_Iron_World "Big Iron World")_ (2006), another
Rawlings production, added a sense of urgency on new songs like "I Hear Them
All". They recorded _[Tennessee Pusher](/wiki/Tennessee_Pusher "Tennessee
Pusher")_ (2008) in Hollywood with producer [Don Was](/wiki/Don_Was "Don
Was"), "rocking harder" with "Alabama High Test" and "Methamphetamine".[10]
Secor says the band "figured they'd take some leftover material from the first
album, add a few traditional songs and suddenly have a new record." But, he
says . .

> . . it wasn't that easy. Pretty soon, after we realized that that wasn't
> going to work that way, the gods up above started sending down some
> lightning bolts of good music and we were able to collect some new
> material—write some and craft some—that has made the record what it is.[34]

Starting with an appearance on radio show _[A Prairie Home Companion with
Garrison Keillor](/wiki/A_Prairie_Home_Companion "A Prairie Home Companion")_
in 2004 [w 9] they've had a recurring engagement with the show, including
several appearances in the show's home state of [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota
"Minnesota") and special live shows—including the [Hollywood
Bowl](/wiki/Hollywood_Bowl "Hollywood Bowl") and a New Year's Eve show at the
Ryman. They've participated in three of the show's [Cinecasts](/wiki/Cinecast
"Cinecast"), all from the [Fitzgerald Theater](/wiki/Fitzgerald_Theater
"Fitzgerald Theater") in Saint Paul, "seen on movie screens across North
America."[w 10][w 11]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Justin_Townes_Earle_and_Gillian_Welch.jpg/225px-
Justin_Townes_Earle_and_Gillian_Welch.jpg)](/wiki/File:Justin_Townes_Earle_and_Gillian_Welch.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Justin_Townes_Earle_and_Gillian_Welch.jpg "Enlarge")

Justin Townes Earle and Gillian Welch appear at debut show for The Big
Surprise Tour at Casino Ballroom in Hampton Beach, New Hampshire August 4,
2009.

_The Big Surprise Tour_ featuring Old Crow, Gillian Welch and Dave Rawlings,
the Felice Brothers, and [Justin Townes Earle](/wiki/Justin_Townes_Earle
"Justin Townes Earle") kicked off in [Hampton Beach, New
Hampshire](/wiki/Hampton_Beach,_New_Hampshire "Hampton Beach, New Hampshire")
August 2009. The "nine-stop tour" included shows in
[Knoxville](/wiki/Knoxville "Knoxville"), Nashville, [Boston](/wiki/Boston
"Boston"), New York and [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia")—and
"mark(ed) the first major showcasing of the Dave Rawlings Machine."[35]

In April 2011 the group joined [Mumford and Sons](/wiki/Mumford_and_Sons
"Mumford and Sons") and [Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic
Zeros](/wiki/Edward_Sharpe_and_the_Magnetic_Zeros "Edward Sharpe and the
Magnetic Zeros") on The Railroad Revival Tour, a tour inspired by the
[Festival Express](/wiki/Festival_Express "Festival Express") tour across
Canada in 1970 that included [Buddy Guy](/wiki/Buddy_Guy "Buddy Guy"), [Janis
Joplin](/wiki/Janis_Joplin "Janis Joplin"), [The Grateful
Dead](/wiki/The_Grateful_Dead "The Grateful Dead"), and [The
Band](/wiki/The_Band "The Band").[15] Traveling exclusively in vintage rail
cars, the three bands performed in six "unique outdoor locations" over the
course of a week starting in [Oakland, California](/wiki/Oakland,_California
"Oakland, California").[w 12] They appear in the musical documentary about the
tour, _Big Easy Express_ directed by Emmett Malloy, which premiered March 2012
at the [South by Southwest Film Conference and
Festival](/wiki/South_by_Southwest "South by Southwest") (SXSW Film) in
[Austin, Texas](/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin, Texas")[l 3]—winning the
Headliner Audience Award.[36]

Ketch Secor on [fiddle](/wiki/Fiddle "Fiddle") at [benefit

_Big Easy Express_ won the [Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music

### Hiatus/Founder
returns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Hiatus/Founder returns")]

In August 2011, the group announced they were on hiatus, cancelling three
shows scheduled for the following month, with "little word from the band on
whether there would continue to be a band."[r 1] Original member Willie
Watson[1] left in Fall of 2011, a couple months before Fuqua returned.[i 9]

Recording of their next album had been largely done before the break.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Chris_Fuqua_with_Old_Crow.jpg/250px-

Chris 'Critter' Fuqua performs with group on acoustic guitar at [9:30
Club](/wiki/9:30_Club "9:30 Club") in [Washington,
D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") on August 2, 2012.

Founding member Fuqua rejoined the group in January 2012, after leaving in
2004 "initially leaving to go to [rehab](/wiki/Drug_rehabilitation "Drug
rehabilitation") for his drinking, then staying out to attend
[college](/wiki/College "College")."[37][i 10] Cory Younts, who left Old Crow
a few months into 2012 to perform in [Jack
White](/wiki/Jack_White_\(musician\) "Jack White \(musician\)")'s [backup
band](/wiki/Backup_band "Backup band") [Los Buzzardos](/wiki/Los_Buzzardos
"Los Buzzardos")[38] (or The Buzzards) on world tour to support White's album
_[Blunderbuss](/wiki/Blunderbuss_\(album\) "Blunderbuss \(album\)")_ ,[39]
returned to the group in 2013.[40][n 11]

### _Carry Me Back_
(2012)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Carry Me Back \(2012\)")]

_Carry Me Back_ was released July 17, 2012 on [According to Our Records (or
ATO Records)](/wiki/ATO_Records "ATO Records"). Founded by [Dave
Matthews](/wiki/Dave_Matthews "Dave Matthews") and his business manager [Coran
Capshaw](/wiki/Coran_Capshaw "Coran Capshaw") in 2000 as a division of [RCA
Records](/wiki/RCA_Records "RCA Records"). Recorded at [Sound Emporium
Studios](/w/index.php?title=Sound_Emporium_Studios&action=edit&redlink=1
"Sound Emporium Studios \(page does not exist\)") in Nashville, the album was
produced by [Ted Hutt](/wiki/Ted_Hutt "Ted Hutt") who had worked with
[Gaslight Anthem](/wiki/Gaslight_Anthem "Gaslight Anthem"), [Dropkick
Murphys](/wiki/Dropkick_Murphys "Dropkick Murphys"), and [Flogging
Molly](/wiki/Flogging_Molly "Flogging Molly").[w 13] The name derives from
"[Carry Me Back to Old Virginny](/wiki/Carry_Me_Back_to_Old_Virginny "Carry Me
Back to Old Virginny")", former official state song of Virginia.[41]

The song "Levi" is "about a soldier who grew up in the wild
[hillbilly](/wiki/Hillbilly "Hillbilly") woods of Virginia."[r 2] First
Lieutenant Leevi Barnard—from [Ararat, Virginia](/wiki/Ararat,_Virginia
"Ararat, Virginia")—on his first tour of duty overseas with the [National
Guard](/wiki/National_Guard_of_the_United_States "National Guard of the United
States"), was "killed by a suicide bomber"[r 2] in [Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad
"Baghdad")'s [Dora
Market](/w/index.php?title=Dora_Market&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dora Market
\(page does not exist\)") in 2009.[i 11] Near the end of the NPR broadcast,
where Secor first heard the story in 2009, several of the late lieutenant's
friends,[41] part of the funeral congregation,[i 5] "broke into Barnard's
favorite song" . . "Wagon Wheel".[41] "Genevieve" by Landry is "an evocative
[eulogy](/wiki/Eulogy "Eulogy") of a [Creole](/wiki/Louisiana_Creole_people
"Louisiana Creole people") queen who steals a young man's heart."[r 2]

The album "sold over 17,000 copies in its debut week, landing at #22 on the
Billboard Albums Chart, leading to both the band's best ever sales week and
their highest ever charting position. It was #1 on both the Bluegrass and Folk
charts and is the #4 Country album in the nation"[w 13] (as of July 31, 2012).
To promote the album, the group played five unannounced shows at historical
locations around Nashville (including one surprise show in front of Ryman
Auditorium)[29] and toured July/August 2012 with [The
Lumineers](/wiki/The_Lumineers "The Lumineers"), [The Milk Carton
Kids](/wiki/The_Milk_Carton_Kids "The Milk Carton Kids"), and [Pokey LaFarge
and the South City Three](/wiki/Pokey_LaFarge "Pokey LaFarge") visiting such
cities as: [Louisville](/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky "Louisville, Kentucky"),
[Cincinnati](/wiki/Cincinnati "Cincinnati"), [Nashville](/wiki/Nashville
"Nashville"), [Richmond](/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia "Richmond, Virginia"),
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."),
[Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia"), New York,
[Boston](/wiki/Boston "Boston"), and [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta").[w 13]

[American Songwriter](/wiki/American_Songwriter "American Songwriter"), and
[London](/wiki/London "London")-based [The Independent](/wiki/The_Independent
"The Independent") and [The Financial Times](/wiki/The_Financial_Times "The
Financial Times"), each gave the album 4 out of 5 stars.[r 3][r 4][r 5] To
Secor the album "is as close as that original inspiration to be in a band as
when we first got started. It's very much the root of our sound."[42]

> _Carry Me Back_ exploits a
> [kaleidoscopic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/kaleidoscopic
> "wikt:Special:Search/kaleidoscopic") galaxy of joyous old-timey string
> sounds updated for the 21st century.[r 2]
>
> — Dave Dawson, _Nu Country_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Kevin_Hayes_on_Guitjo_with_Old_Crow_Medicine_Show.jpg/225px-
Kevin_Hayes_on_Guitjo_with_Old_Crow_Medicine_Show.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kevin_Hayes_on_Guitjo_with_Old_Crow_Medicine_Show.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kevin_Hayes_on_Guitjo_with_Old_Crow_Medicine_Show.jpg "Enlarge")

Kevin Hayes plays [guitjo](/wiki/Guitjo_\(six-string\) "Guitjo \(six-
string\)") with Old Crow Medicine Show at Tivoli Theatre in Chattanooga,
Tennessee on May 5, 2010, adding a unique sound.

Chance McCoy—who grew up in [Harpers Ferry, West
Virginia](/wiki/Harpers_Ferry,_West_Virginia "Harpers Ferry, West Virginia"),
but was born in Washington, D.C.[43]—joined just prior to the _Carry Me Back_
promotional tour in 2012. As a teacher of old-time music at [Augusta Heritage
Center](/wiki/Augusta_Heritage_Center "Augusta Heritage Center") of [Davis &
Elkins College](/wiki/Davis_%26_Elkins_College "Davis & Elkins College") in
[Elkins, West Virginia](/wiki/Elkins,_West_Virginia "Elkins, West Virginia")
he'd attracted the attention of the group who "wanted to get Old Crow back
together and on the road again."[i 12] "He got the gig" because Secor "knew
that anyone who worked at Augusta knew all about old-time music."[40]

### _Remedy_
(2014)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Remedy \(2014\)")]

The group's ninth album, _Remedy_ , was released in July 2014 by [ATO
Records](/wiki/ATO_Records "ATO Records") and produced by Ted Hutt—who
produced their previous studio record. The album features a collaboration with
Bob Dylan, "Sweet Amarillo", and ballads "Dearly Departed Friend" and
"Firewater", the latter written by Fuqua.[44] _Remedy_ won the [Grammy Award
for Best Folk Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Folk_Album "Grammy Award for
Best Folk Album") in 2015.[3] This award—created in 2012 to address
"challenges in distinguishing between" previous category [Best Contemporary
Folk Album](/wiki/Best_Contemporary_Folk_Album "Best Contemporary Folk Album")
and [Best Traditional Folk Album](/wiki/Best_Traditional_Folk_Album "Best
Traditional Folk Album") musical genres[45]—was won by [Guy
Clark](/wiki/Guy_Clark "Guy Clark") the previous year and [Béla
Fleck](/wiki/B%C3%A9la_Fleck "Béla Fleck") & [Abigail
Washburn](/wiki/Abigail_Washburn "Abigail Washburn") the next. Also nominated
in 2015 were [Mike Auldridge](/wiki/Mike_Auldridge "Mike Auldridge"), [Jerry
Douglas](/wiki/Jerry_Douglas "Jerry Douglas") & [Rob Ickes](/wiki/Rob_Ickes
"Rob Ickes") for _Three Bells_ , [Alice Gerrard](/wiki/Alice_Gerrard "Alice
Gerrard") for _Follow the Music_ , [Eliza Gilkyson](/wiki/Eliza_Gilkyson
"Eliza Gilkyson") for _The Nocturen Diaries_ , and [Jesse
Winchester](/wiki/Jesse_Winchester "Jesse Winchester") (1944-2014) for _A
Reasonable Amount of Trouble_.

### _Blonde on Blonde_
(2017)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Blonde on Blonde \(2017\)")]

The group released _50 Years of Blonde on Blonde_ on April 28, 2017 on their
new label [Columbia Nashville](/wiki/Columbia_Nashville "Columbia
Nashville").[9] The album pays tribute to Dylan's 1966 masterpiece _[Blonde on
Blonde](/wiki/Blonde_on_Blonde "Blonde on Blonde")_ with live recordings of
the group's re-creation of it at the [Country Music Hall of Fame and
Museum](/wiki/Country_Music_Hall_of_Fame_and_Museum "Country Music Hall of
Fame and Museum") in Nashville in May 2016.

The project doubles as the group's first release for the Columbia label, which
also released _Blonde on Blonde_. They announced their addition to the roster
with an impromptu performance of "[Rainy Day Women #12 &
35](/wiki/Rainy_Day_Women_%E2%99%AF12_%26_35 "Rainy Day Women ♯12 & 35")" from
the Dylan album. In support of the album release, Secor states:

> Fifty years is a long time for a place like Nashville, Tennessee. Time rolls
> on slowly around here like flotsam and jetsam in the muddy [Cumberland
> River](/wiki/Cumberland_River "Cumberland River"). But certain things have
> accelerated the pace of our city. And certain people have sent the hands of
> the clock spinning. Bob Dylan is the greatest of these time-bending,
> paradigm-shifting Nashville cats.[46]

### _Volunteer_
(2018)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Volunteer \(2018\)")]

Old Crow Medicine Show released their sixth studio album, _Volunteer_ ,
through Columbia Nashville on April 20, 2018 — coinciding with their 20th
anniversary as a group. The album was recorded at Nashville's "historic" RCA
Studio A with Americana "super-producer" [Dave Cobb](/wiki/Dave_Cobb "Dave
Cobb"), who known for his work with [Jason Isbell](/wiki/Jason_Isbell "Jason
Isbell") and [Chris Stapleton](/wiki/Chris_Stapleton "Chris Stapleton"). The
album features electric guitar for the first time since 2004[47] — when David
Rawlings added his Telecaster to "Wagon Wheel".[48] Joe Jackson Andrews plays
[pedal steel guitar](/wiki/Pedal_steel_guitar "Pedal steel guitar").[47] As
quoted in [Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard \(magazine\)"),
Secor says of the album's sound:[49]

> Because we were working with Dave, we wanted to pull out some of our more, I
> guess, rockin' sounds and do less of a roots music or old time acoustic
> record. We wanted to have it be a little bigger. We were in a big room, RCA
> Studio A as opposed to Studio B, and a lot of times the music kind of
> matches the space.

"Look Away" is a "Rolling Stones-inspired tribute to the history of the
American South," while "A World Away" is an "upbeat homage to refugees."
"Dixie Avenue" is a wistful tribute to the place in Virginia where Secor and
Fuqua first "fell in love with music." The closing song "Whirlwind" is a
"bittersweet love song that could easily describe Old Crow Medicine's rise to
prominence from the ground up."[48]

The lead single "Flicker & Shine" was released January 19, 2018.[48]

## Musical
style[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Musical style")]

The sound is invigorating on their recordings, but at a live show the fiddle,
banjo, and harmonica are practically on fire, creating a crazy, addictive mix
of some of the best traditional music America has to offer with the intensity
of a modern-day rock show.[8]

— Elizabeth Pandolfi, [Charleston City Paper](/wiki/Charleston_City_Paper
"Charleston City Paper")

Variously described as old-time, [Americana](/wiki/Americana_\(music\)
"Americana \(music\)"), [bluegrass](/wiki/Bluegrass_music "Bluegrass music"),
[alternative country](/wiki/Alternative_country "Alternative country"), and
"[folk-country](/wiki/Country_folk "Country folk")", the group started out
infusing old Appalachian sounds with new [punk](/wiki/Punk_rock "Punk rock")
energy. [Country Music Television](/wiki/Country_Music_Television "Country
Music Television") notes their "tunes from [jug bands](/wiki/Jug_band "Jug
band") and traveling shows, back porches and dance halls, southern
[Appalachian](/wiki/Appalachia "Appalachia") [string music](/wiki/String_band
"String band") and [Memphis blues](/wiki/Memphis_blues "Memphis blues")."[w
14] Gabrielle Gray, executive director of the [International Bluegrass Music
Museum](/wiki/International_Bluegrass_Music_Museum "International Bluegrass
Music Museum")—who sponsors ROMP: Bluegrass Roots & Branches Festival, which
Old Crow headlined one night in 2012—holds the group "is in the direction of
[progressive bluegrass](/wiki/Progressive_bluegrass "Progressive
bluegrass")."[l 4] Their live touring show has been described as a "folk-
bluegrass-alt-country blend."[r 6]

"We just knew we wanted to combine the technical side of the old sound with
the energy of a [Nirvana](/wiki/Nirvana_\(band\) "Nirvana \(band\)")," states
Fuqua.[i 13] Starting from old-time music in the Appalachian hills, the group
found themselves "making a foray into electric instruments and 'really
knocking up the [rock 'n' roll](/wiki/Rock_and_roll "Rock and roll") tree' on
their 2008 release 'Tennessee Pusher'." On the documentary "Big Easy Express"
about the _Railroad Revival Tour_ with Mumford & Sons and Edward Sharpe and
the Magnetic Zeros they "practice(d) a complementary variation of folk"
bringing "a pleasingly smoky
[amalgam](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/amalgam
"wikt:Special:Search/amalgam") of country, bluegrass, and blues."[r 7] With
"Carry Me Back" (2012) they've "circled back to the original sound that so
excited (Secor) and Fuqua as kids . . full of old-timey string sounds updated
for the 21st century – [sing-a-longs](/wiki/Sing-along "Sing-along") that lift
the soul, [ballads](/wiki/Ballad "Ballad") that rend the heart and a few
moments of pure exhilaration."[42]

###
Songwriting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Songwriting")]

It takes a lot to figure out how to keep one foot in old time and one foot in
all time. It's a bit of a dance to be rooted and modern at the same time. I
think we've figured out how to write those songs that sound like they were
sung by some campfire 85 years ago, but sound good blasted from the stereo of
a [Ford Ranchero](/wiki/Ford_Ranchero "Ford Ranchero") in a [Burger
King](/wiki/Burger_King "Burger King") parking lot somewhere outside of
[Enid](/wiki/Enid,_Oklahoma "Enid, Oklahoma").[28]

— Ketch Secor

Early on the group didn't perform songs they'd written, instead drawing on a
storehouse of pre-war [jug band](/wiki/Jug_band "Jug band"), string band,
[minstrel show](/wiki/Minstrel_show "Minstrel show"), blues and folk fare. As
with other young groups in the genre, driven by all that punk music energy,
they played this old material "fast and hard".[50] When they started writing
original material they distinguished themselves "from the crowded field of New
Wave string bands as genuine stars. And both groups have done it by writing
new songs more ambitious than mere rewrites of old
[hillbilly](/wiki/Hillbilly_music "Hillbilly music") and blues numbers."[50]
Songs they write often have a socially conscious theme, such as "I Hear Them
All", "Ways Of Man", "Ain't It Enough", and "Levi".

Secor admits to developing "the habit of writing what he calls 'stolen melody
songs'"—in much the same way he'd created "Wagon Wheel", carrying on in the
folk tradition—"like when he penned fresh, war tax-themed lyrics to a tune
that had already passed through other wholesale re-writes during its descent
from old-time [Scots-Irish](/wiki/Scotch-Irish_American "Scotch-Irish
American") [balladry](/wiki/Balladry "Balladry")."[37] Dave Rawlings states:
"I've always thought that a really important thing that the Old Crow Medicine
Show brought to the table was new songs—some reinterpreted old ones, some
really nicely written and brand new—with the old flavor, but also with that
vitality."[35]

In August 2014, [Downtown Music Publishing](/wiki/Downtown_Music_Publishing
"Downtown Music Publishing") signed a worldwide publishing agreement with Old
Crow Medicine Show. This agreement covers all five of the band's studio
albums, including '[Remedy](/wiki/Remedy_\(Old_Crow_Medicine_Show_album\)
"Remedy \(Old Crow Medicine Show album\)")'.[18]

###
Influences[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Influences")]

An early Secor influence was [John Hartford](/wiki/John_Hartford "John
Hartford") who performed for his first grade class in
[Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), making him want "to play the banjo
after that;"[i 1] and the first song he ever learned to play was [Tom
Paxton](/wiki/Tom_Paxton "Tom Paxton")'s "[Ramblin' Boy](/wiki/Ramblin%27_Boy
"Ramblin' Boy")".[19]:6 [Guns N' Roses](/wiki/Guns_N%27_Roses "Guns N' Roses")
was Fuqua's "first influence": when they released _[Appetite for
Destruction](/wiki/Appetite_for_Destruction "Appetite for Destruction")_
(1987), while he was in seventh grade, he knew he wanted to be a musician. He
also claims AC/DC and Nirvana as influences "and then into blues and then into
more obscure fiddlers. Some [Conjunto](/wiki/Conjunto "Conjunto") from down in
[San Antonio](/wiki/San_Antonio,_Texas "San Antonio, Texas")."[i 14] "Take 'Em
Away", written when he was 17, is "loosely based on [Mance
Lipscomb](/wiki/Mance_Lipscomb "Mance Lipscomb"), a blues singer and
[sharecropper](/wiki/Sharecropper "Sharecropper") from [Navasota
County](/wiki/Navasota_County,_Texas "Navasota County, Texas")" who he says
"was a big influence on me."[i 14]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Gill_Landry_with_Old_Crow.jpg/200px-
Gill_Landry_with_Old_Crow.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gill_Landry_with_Old_Crow.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gill_Landry_with_Old_Crow.jpg "Enlarge")

Gill Landry plays resonator guitar with Old Crow Medicine Show at 9:30 Club in
Washington, D.C. on August 2, 2012.

Naming his major influences, Secor states: "Certainly, Bob Dylan . . Bob Dylan
. . Bob Dylan. More than anything else. More than any book or song or story or
play. The work and the recorded work of Bob Dylan. It's the most profound
influence on me. And then the other people that really influenced me tend to
be the same people who influenced Bob Dylan."[i 1] Fuqua concurs on Dylan's
influence:

> He's a link to Woody Guthrie, who's a link to an even earlier form of
> American music history. He's . . a great doorway for all sorts of artists
> because he's not just folk, or just rock. . . I think bands like us, Mumford
> and Sons, and Gillian Welch and David Rawlings are sort of doing what he has
> done before, in that we take our own experiences and observations and put
> them into songs made of traditional, American roots form. That form is still
> a great vehicle for songs, whether the song is about love, the Iraq War or
> anything else.[i 14]

The Dylan doorway led to the first recordings of the [New Lost City
Ramblers](/wiki/New_Lost_City_Ramblers "New Lost City Ramblers"), the [Jim
Kweskin Jug Band](/wiki/Jim_Kweskin "Jim Kweskin"), [Canned
Heat](/wiki/Canned_Heat "Canned Heat"), [The Lovin'
Spoonful](/wiki/The_Lovin%27_Spoonful "The Lovin' Spoonful"), Dylan and [The
Band](/wiki/The_Band "The Band") in the basement, and the [Grateful
Dead](/wiki/Grateful_Dead "Grateful Dead").[31]

###
Impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Impact")]

While it would be going a bit far to say Old Crow sparked a full-blown folk
revival, these guys have contributed mightily to a major shift in youthful
attitudes toward ownership, authenticity and what it means to feel included in
a musical experience: lyrics don't have to be strict autobiography to connect;
songs don't have to be entirely original to showcase originality; and younger
generations need not turn up their noses at music that doesn't treat them like
they're at the center of the universe.[37]

— Jewly Hight, [American Songwriter](/wiki/American_Songwriter "American
Songwriter")

When Secor, Fuqua, and company first got together "old-timey pickers their age
were few and far between. Modern rock was still a force to be reckoned with.
Now hard-driving string bands are where it's at."[51] Fuqua recalls:

> When we started the band in '98, you didn't see anybody our age playing
> banjos or upright basses or fiddles, or playing this music. I mean, you did
> if you went to the fiddle festivals at [Mt.
> Airy](/wiki/Mt._Airy,_North_Carolina "Mt. Airy, North Carolina") or in
> [Galax, Virginia](/wiki/Galax,_Virginia "Galax, Virginia"). But . . now you
> throw a stone in any direction . . you'll hit someone in a band who's . .
> playing banjo or playing these old-time tunes.[51]

To [Americana Music Association](/wiki/Americana_Music_Association "Americana
Music Association") (AMA) President Jed Hilly, the historic path of Americana
music passes through the group: "The baton is passed from Emmylou Harris to
Gillian Welch and David Rawlings to Old Crow Medicine Show to the Avett
Brothers."[51] Emmylou Harris was, in fact . .

> . . among the gateway artists who helped Mumford and bandmates Ben Lovett,
> Ted Dwane and Winston Marshall discover their love for American roots music.
> It started with the ['O Brother, Where Art Thou?'
> soundtrack](/wiki/O_Brother,_Where_Art_Thou%3F_\(soundtrack\) "O Brother,
> Where Art Thou? \(soundtrack\)") . . That eventually led them to the Old
> Crow Medicine Show and then deep immersion in old-timey sounds from
> America's long-neglected past.[6]

You can't swing a cat these days without hitting a
[hipster](/wiki/Hipster_\(contemporary_subculture\) "Hipster \(contemporary
subculture\)") with a banjo in his hands. At least part of the credit for this
phenomenon goes to Old Crow Medicine Show.[7]

— Chrissie Dickinson, [Chicago Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Tribune "Chicago
Tribune")

Marcus Mumford, [front man](/wiki/Lead_vocalist#Frontperson "Lead vocalist")
of Mumford & Sons, recognizes the group's influence: "I first heard Old Crow's
music when I was, like, 16, 17, and that really got me into, like, folk music,
bluegrass. I mean, I'd listened to a lot of Dylan, but I hadn't really
ventured into the country world so much. So Old Crow were the band that made
me fall in love with country music."[37] Mumford acknowledges in "Big Easy
Express", Emmett Malloy's "moving documentary" about the vintage train tour
they'd invited Old Crow to join them on, that "the band inspired them to pick
up the banjo and start their now famous country nights in
[London](/wiki/London "London")."

Old Crow received the 2013 Trailblazer Award from the [Americana Music
Association](/wiki/Americana_Music_Association "Americana Music
Association").[17]

distinctions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=17

  * Their music video of "I Hear Them All" (from _Big Iron World_) was first-round finalist in both CMT Award categories in which it was nominated.[53] Directed by [Danny Clinch](/wiki/Danny_Clinch "Danny Clinch"), the video was shot in the Mid-City area of [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans") featuring local residents with inspirational stories about surviving [Hurricane Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina").
  * For the [Americana Music Award](/wiki/Americana_Music_Award "Americana Music Award") show held November 1, 2007 at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville they joined [Uncle Earl](/wiki/Uncle_Earl "Uncle Earl"), [Sunny Sweeney](/wiki/Sunny_Sweeney "Sunny Sweeney"), [Todd Snider](/wiki/Todd_Snider "Todd Snider"), [The Avett Brothers](/wiki/The_Avett_Brothers "The Avett Brothers"), [Guy Clark](/wiki/Guy_Clark "Guy Clark"), [Emmylou Harris](/wiki/Emmylou_Harris "Emmylou Harris"), the [Hacienda Brothers](/wiki/Hacienda_Brothers "Hacienda Brothers"), [Elizabeth Cook](/wiki/Elizabeth_Cook "Elizabeth Cook"), [Amy LaVere](/wiki/Amy_LaVere "Amy LaVere"), and [Ricky Skaggs](/wiki/Ricky_Skaggs "Ricky Skaggs") with [Bruce Hornsby](/wiki/Bruce_Hornsby "Bruce Hornsby") as performers on stage.[l 5]
  * The group performed during the 12th Annual [Americana Honors & Awards Show](/wiki/Americana_Music_Honors_%26_Awards "Americana Music Honors & Awards"), which took place September 18, 2013 at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, sharing stage with such acts as [Stephen Stills](/wiki/Stephen_Stills "Stephen Stills"), [Richard Thompson](/wiki/Richard_Thompson_\(musician\) "Richard Thompson \(musician\)"), Emmylou Harris, and [Rodney Crowell](/wiki/Rodney_Crowell "Rodney Crowell").[17]
  * Darius Rucker's version of "Wagon Wheel" was nominated for Single of the Year along with [Florida Georgia Line](/wiki/Florida_Georgia_Line "Florida Georgia Line") ("Cruise"), Tim McGraw with Taylor Swift & [Keith Urban](/wiki/Keith_Urban "Keith Urban") ("Highway Don't Care"), [Miranda Lambert](/wiki/Miranda_Lambert "Miranda Lambert") ("Mama's Broken Heart"), and [Kacey Musgraves](/wiki/Kacey_Musgraves "Kacey Musgraves") ("Merry Go 'Round").[l 6]
  * Rucker sang the song to close out the televised CMA awards ceremony November 6, 2013.[54]

## Honors and
distinctions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Honors and distinctions")]

  * Old Crow Medicine Show performed on a float for the 2003 [Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade](/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade "Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade").[55]
  * They opened for the [Dave Matthews Band](/wiki/Dave_Matthews_Band "Dave Matthews Band") in 2009 at the [John Paul Jones Arena](/wiki/John_Paul_Jones_Arena "John Paul Jones Arena") in Charlottesville, VA; the [Verizon Wireless Music Center](/wiki/Verizon_Wireless_Music_Center_\(Birmingham\) "Verizon Wireless Music Center \(Birmingham\)") in [Pelham, AL](/wiki/Pelham,_AL "Pelham, AL"); and the [Nikon at Jones Beach Theater](/wiki/Nikon_at_Jones_Beach_Theater "Nikon at Jones Beach Theater") in [Wantagh, NY](/wiki/Wantagh,_NY "Wantagh, NY").
  * The band headlined at the [Grand Ole Opry](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry "Grand Ole Opry"),[i 4] after earlier having performed at that institution's 75th-anniversary celebration,[56] and appeared in special [New Year's Eve](/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve "New Year's Eve") shows in 2009 (with special guest Chuck Mead)[l 7] and 2010[w 15] at the [Ryman Auditorium](/wiki/Ryman_Auditorium "Ryman Auditorium") in [Nashville](/wiki/Nashville,_TN "Nashville, TN").
  * Their recording of "[Wagon Wheel](/wiki/Wagon_Wheel_\(song\) "Wagon Wheel \(song\)")" was certified [platinum](/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification "Music recording sales certification") by the [Recording Industry Association of America](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry Association of America") in April 2013.[13]
  * The music documentary _[Big Easy Express](/wiki/Edward_Sharpe_and_the_Magnetic_Zeros#Big_Easy_Express "Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros")_ , in which the band was featured along with [Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros](/wiki/Edward_Sharpe_and_the_Magnetic_Zeros "Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros") and [Mumford and Sons](/wiki/Mumford_and_Sons "Mumford and Sons"), won a [Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music Video](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Long_Form_Music_Video "Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music Video") in 2013. Directed by Emmett Malloy, the video was produced by Bryan Ling, Mike Luba, and Tim Lynch under the S2BN Films label.[w 1]
  * Old Crow Medicine Show was formally inducted into the [Grand Ole Opry](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry "Grand Ole Opry") at a special ceremony at the [Grand Ole Opry House](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry_House "Grand Ole Opry House") in Nashville on September 17, 2013.[2] They join other group Opry members like [Gatlin Brothers](/wiki/Gatlin_Brothers "Gatlin Brothers"), [Oak Ridge Boys](/wiki/Oak_Ridge_Boys "Oak Ridge Boys"), [Osborne Brothers](/wiki/Osborne_Brothers "Osborne Brothers"), and [Rascal Flatts](/wiki/Rascal_Flatts "Rascal Flatts")—and individual member acts [Roy Clark](/wiki/Roy_Clark "Roy Clark"), [Clint Black](/wiki/Clint_Black "Clint Black"), [Garth Brooks](/wiki/Garth_Brooks "Garth Brooks"), [Charlie Daniels](/wiki/Charlie_Daniels "Charlie Daniels"), [Vince Gill](/wiki/Vince_Gill "Vince Gill"), [Emmylou Harris](/wiki/Emmylou_Harris "Emmylou Harris"), [Tom T. Hall](/wiki/Tom_T._Hall "Tom T. Hall"), [Alison Krauss](/wiki/Alison_Krauss "Alison Krauss"), [Loretta Lynn](/wiki/Loretta_Lynn "Loretta Lynn"), [Patti Loveless](/wiki/Patti_Loveless "Patti Loveless"), [Del McCoury](/wiki/Del_McCoury "Del McCoury"), [Charley Pride](/wiki/Charley_Pride "Charley Pride"), and [Ricky Scaggs](/wiki/Ricky_Scaggs "Ricky Scaggs").[w 16]

##
Commemorations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Commemorations")]

  * Old Crow Medicine Show performed "Tell Mother I Will Meet Her" at the induction of [Emmylou Harris](/wiki/Emmylou_Harris "Emmylou Harris") and [Ernest V. "Pop" Stoneman](/wiki/Ernest_Stoneman "Ernest Stoneman") into the [Country Music Hall of Fame](/wiki/Country_Music_Hall_of_Fame "Country Music Hall of Fame") April 27, 2008.[w 17]
  * The group helped celebrate the life of the [Hardly Strictly Bluegrass](/wiki/Hardly_Strictly_Bluegrass "Hardly Strictly Bluegrass") festival founder/benefactor Warren Hellman at a free tribute concert in [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco "San Francisco") February 19, 2012, appearing with such acts as [John Doe](/wiki/John_Doe "John Doe"), [Dry Branch Fire Squad](/wiki/Dry_Branch_Fire_Squad "Dry Branch Fire Squad"), [Steve Earle](/wiki/Steve_Earle "Steve Earle"), [The Wronglers](/w/index.php?title=The_Wronglers&action=edit&redlink=1 "The Wronglers \(page does not exist\)") with [Jimmie Dale Gilmore](/wiki/Jimmie_Dale_Gilmore "Jimmie Dale Gilmore"), [Gillian Welch](/wiki/Gillian_Welch "Gillian Welch"), [Boz Scaggs](/wiki/Boz_Scaggs "Boz Scaggs"), and [Emmylou Harris](/wiki/Emmylou_Harris "Emmylou Harris").[l 8]
  * They took part in the Woody Guthrie Centennial Celebration Concert _This Land Is Your Land_ March 10, 2012 at the [Brady Theater](/wiki/Brady_Theater "Brady Theater") in [Tulsa, Oklahoma](/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma "Tulsa, Oklahoma"), performing classic [Woody Guthrie](/wiki/Woody_Guthrie "Woody Guthrie") songs with [Arlo Guthrie](/wiki/Arlo_Guthrie "Arlo Guthrie"), [John Mellencamp](/wiki/John_Mellencamp "John Mellencamp"), [Jackson Browne](/wiki/Jackson_Browne "Jackson Browne"),[l 9] [Rosanne Cash](/wiki/Rosanne_Cash "Rosanne Cash"), [Del McCoury Band](/wiki/Del_McCoury_Band "Del McCoury Band"), [The Flaming Lips](/wiki/The_Flaming_Lips "The Flaming Lips"), [Hanson](/wiki/Hanson_\(band\) "Hanson \(band\)"), [Tim O'Brien](/wiki/Tim_O%27Brien_\(musician\) "Tim O'Brien \(musician\)"), and [Jimmy LaFave](/wiki/Jimmy_LaFave "Jimmy LaFave").[w 18]
  * The group performed with such acts as [John Mellencamp](/wiki/John_Mellencamp "John Mellencamp"), [Jackson Browne](/wiki/Jackson_Browne "Jackson Browne"), [Dropkick Murphys](/wiki/Dropkick_Murphys "Dropkick Murphys"), [Tom Morello](/wiki/Tom_Morello "Tom Morello"), and [Arlo Guthrie](/wiki/Arlo_Guthrie "Arlo Guthrie") at [The Kennedy Center](/wiki/The_Kennedy_Center "The Kennedy Center"), in collaboration with the [Grammy Museum](/wiki/Grammy_Museum_at_L.A._Live "Grammy Museum at L.A. Live"), to celebrate the life and work of folk singer and icon [Woody Guthrie](/wiki/Woody_Guthrie "Woody Guthrie") on October 14, 2012 at The Kennedy Center Concert Hall.[l 10]
  * The group joined [Charley Pride](/wiki/Charley_Pride "Charley Pride") and [Connie Smith](/wiki/Connie_Smith "Connie Smith"), wife of [Marty Stuart](/wiki/Marty_Stuart "Marty Stuart"), when he celebrated his 20th year as a member of the Grand Ole Opry December 8, 2012 at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville.[57]

##
Broadcast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Broadcast")]

  * Old Crow Medicine Show made their national television debut on [CMT](/wiki/Country_Music_Television "Country Music Television")'s [Grand Ole Opry Live](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry_Live "Grand Ole Opry Live") in 2002.[w 14]
  * They appeared on _[Late Night with Conan O'Brien](/wiki/Late_Night_with_Conan_O%27Brien "Late Night with Conan O'Brien")_ with [Lauren Graham](/wiki/Lauren_Graham "Lauren Graham") and [Paula Abdul](/wiki/Paula_Abdul "Paula Abdul") on May 7, 2004 [Season 11, Episode 109][w 19] and again on December 23, 2008—appearing with [Dustin Hoffman](/wiki/Dustin_Hoffman "Dustin Hoffman") and [Greg Giraldo](/wiki/Greg_Giraldo "Greg Giraldo") [Season 16, Episode 65].[w 20]
  * The group appeared on _[Austin City Limits](/wiki/Austin_City_Limits "Austin City Limits")_ —after [Lucinda Williams](/wiki/Lucinda_Williams "Lucinda Williams")—in a segment aired December 2007 (taped September 2007).[w 21]
  * They make frequent guest appearances on _[A Prairie Home Companion](/wiki/A_Prairie_Home_Companion "A Prairie Home Companion")_ with [Garrison Keillor](/wiki/Garrison_Keillor "Garrison Keillor"), including October 23, 2011 on a live [Cinecast](/wiki/Cinecast "Cinecast") of the show from the [Fitzgerald Theater](/wiki/Fitzgerald_Theater "Fitzgerald Theater") in St.Paul, "seen on movie screens across North America," with [Nickel Creek](/wiki/Nickel_Creek "Nickel Creek")'s Sara Watkins, [Joe Ely](/wiki/Joe_Ely "Joe Ely"), etc.[w 10] [Purdue Convocations](/wiki/Purdue_University "Purdue University") presents a live broadcast performance of the show from the [Elliott Hall of Music](/wiki/Purdue_University "Purdue University") at [Purdue University](/wiki/Purdue_University "Purdue University") in [West Lafayette, Indiana](/wiki/West_Lafayette,_Indiana "West Lafayette, Indiana") in partnership with WBAA 920AM 101.3FM [Public Radio from Purdue](/wiki/Purdue_University "Purdue University") with the group and [Purdue Varsity Glee Club](/wiki/Purdue_University "Purdue University") on October 27, 2012.[w 22]
  * Ketch Secor and Chris "Critter" Fuqua were interviewed on NPR Weekend Edition Sunday July 8, 2012—"Old Crow Medicine Show: Something Borrowed" [10 min 15 sec]."[i 15]
  * The group appear in the PBS broadcast of Woody Guthrie AT 100! LIVE AT THE KENNEDY CENTER, recorded live October 14, 2012 at the [John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts "John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts") in Washington, D.C., and broadcast on PBS stations beginning June 1, 2013. The centennial concert, honoring Guthrie and his music, also featured [Jackson Browne](/wiki/Jackson_Browne "Jackson Browne"), [Donovan](/wiki/Donovan "Donovan"), [Ani DiFranco](/wiki/Ani_DiFranco "Ani DiFranco") with [Ry Cooder](/wiki/Ry_Cooder "Ry Cooder"), [Rosanne Cash](/wiki/Rosanne_Cash "Rosanne Cash"), [The Del McCoury Band](/wiki/The_Del_McCoury_Band "The Del McCoury Band") with [Tim O'Brien](/wiki/Tim_O%27Brien_\(musician\) "Tim O'Brien \(musician\)"), [John Mellencamp](/wiki/John_Mellencamp "John Mellencamp"), etc. Old Crow performed "[Union Maid](/wiki/Union_Maid "Union Maid")"—and "[This Land Is Your Land](/wiki/This_Land_Is_Your_Land "This Land Is Your Land")" and "[This Train Is Bound for Glory](/wiki/This_Train_Is_Bound_for_Glory "This Train Is Bound for Glory")" with all performers. The concert was produced and directed by four-time [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award")-winning filmmaker Jim Brown, and produced in collaboration with [The GRAMMY Museum Foundation](/w/index.php?title=The_GRAMMY_Museum_Foundation&action=edit&redlink=1 "The GRAMMY Museum Foundation \(page does not exist\)").[l 11]
  * The group appeared on an episode of _[CMT Crossroads](/wiki/CMT_Crossroads "CMT Crossroads")_ with [Kesha](/wiki/Kesha "Kesha") which aired on December 6, 2017.[l 12]

##
Film[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Film")]

  * Old Crow Medicine Show performed on the soundtrack for the film _[Transamerica](/wiki/Transamerica_\(film\) "Transamerica \(film\)")_ in 2005, which was nominated for a number of awards—including two [Academy Award](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") nominations—winning several around the world. "Critter" Fuqua wrote "Take 'Em Away" while "We're All in This Together" was written by Ketch Secor and Willie Watson.[w 23]
  * They appeared in the [PBS](/wiki/Public_Broadcast_Service "Public Broadcast Service") American Roots Music series; "In the Valley Where Time Stands Still", a film about the history of the [Renfro Valley Barn Dance](/wiki/Renfro_Valley_Barn_Dance "Renfro Valley Barn Dance");[w 14] and "Bluegrass Journey", a portrait of the contemporary bluegrass scene.[w 24]
  * They appeared in the musical documentary _Big Easy Express_ , directed by Emmett Malloy, being made of The Railroad Revival Tour, which premiered March 2012 at the [South by Southwest Film Conference and Festival](/wiki/South_by_Southwest "South by Southwest") (SXSW Film) in [Austin, Texas](/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin, Texas")[l 3]—winning the Headliner Audience Award.[36]

  * _Caroline_ (2008) Nettwerk - Three track single featuring previously unreleased song "Back to New Orleans"
  * _Carry Me Back to Virginia_ (2013) Three track single featuring a cover of "[Dixieland Delight](/wiki/Dixieland_Delight "Dixieland Delight")" by [Alabama](/wiki/Alabama_\(band\) "Alabama \(band\)")
  * _Brushy Mountain Conjugal Trailer_ (2015) Four track single featuring the previously unreleased "Mother Church", a live version of "The Warden", and "I Done Wrong Blues" (previously released as a B-Side on the "Sweet Amarillo" 7").

###
Contributions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Contributions")]

  * Old Crow Medicine Show performed "Take 'Em Away" (by Fuqua) and "We're All in This Together" (by Secor and Watson) on the [soundtrack for the film](/wiki/Transamerica_\(soundtrack\) "Transamerica \(soundtrack\)") _[Transamerica](/wiki/Transamerica_\(film\) "Transamerica \(film\)")_ (2005). The film was nominated for a number of awards—including two [Oscars](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award")—winning several worldwide.[w 23]
  * They perform [Woody Guthrie](/wiki/Woody_Guthrie "Woody Guthrie")'s "[Deportee (Plane Wreck at Los Gatos)](/wiki/Deportee_\(Plane_Wreck_at_Los_Gatos\) "Deportee \(Plane Wreck at Los Gatos\)")" (Disc 2/Track 15) on _[Song of America](/wiki/Song_of_America_\(album\) "Song of America \(album\)")_ (2007), a 3-CD set tracing the history of the U.S. through new versions of songs by major artists. Produced by Split Rock Records/Thirty One Tigers. Proceeds benefit the [Center for American Music](/w/index.php?title=Center_for_American_Music&action=edit&redlink=1 "Center for American Music \(page does not exist\)"), [National History Day](/wiki/National_History_Day "National History Day"), and [Folk Alliance](/wiki/Folk_Alliance "Folk Alliance").[w 25]
  * Secor wrote, arranged, and performs "Send No Angels" with Lani Marsh on _Our Christmas Present: 2008_ , a fundraising album for [Our Community Place](http://ourcommunityplace.org/) in Harrisonburg, Virginia as a favor to founder/director Ron Copeland, who was owner of Little Grill when/where his and Fuqua's music careers began.[67]:4b[i 10]
  * The group recorded "[Angel From Montgomery](/wiki/Angel_From_Montgomery "Angel From Montgomery")" for _[Broken Hearts& Dirty Windows: Songs of John Prine](/wiki/Broken_Hearts_%26_Dirty_Windows:_Songs_of_John_Prine "Broken Hearts & Dirty Windows: Songs of John Prine")_ (2010), an album celebrating Prine's rich and influential catalog, joining other artists contributing such as [Justin Vernon](/wiki/Justin_Vernon "Justin Vernon") of [Bon Iver](/wiki/Bon_Iver "Bon Iver"), [My Morning Jacket](/wiki/My_Morning_Jacket "My Morning Jacket"), [Josh Ritter](/wiki/Josh_Ritter "Josh Ritter"), [The Avett Brothers](/wiki/The_Avett_Brothers "The Avett Brothers"), [Conor Oberst & The Mystic Valley Band](/wiki/Conor_Oberst_%26_The_Mystic_Valley_Band "Conor Oberst & The Mystic Valley Band"), [Drive-By Truckers](/wiki/Drive-By_Truckers "Drive-By Truckers"), [Lambchop](/wiki/Lambchop_\(band\) "Lambchop \(band\)"), and [Justin Townes Earle](/wiki/Justin_Townes_Earle "Justin Townes Earle").[w 27]
  * Old Crow Medicine Show appear on "veteran roots/Americana band" [Marley's Ghost](/wiki/Marley%27s_Ghost "Marley's Ghost") album _Jubilee_ , released June 2012 on [Sage Arts](/w/index.php?title=Sage_Arts&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sage Arts \(page does not exist\)"), celebrating their 25th anniversary. Recorded at Nashville's [Sound Emporium](/w/index.php?title=Sound_Emporium&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sound Emporium \(page does not exist\)") and produced by [Cowboy Jack Clement](/wiki/Cowboy_Jack_Clement "Cowboy Jack Clement"), the album features other "full-on collaborations between the band and their friends" such as [Emmylou Harris](/wiki/Emmylou_Harris "Emmylou Harris"), [John Prine](/wiki/John_Prine "John Prine"), [Marty Stuart](/wiki/Marty_Stuart "Marty Stuart"), and [Larry Campbell](/wiki/Larry_Campbell "Larry Campbell"). The album cover a wide variety of classic American songwriters including [Kris Kristofferson](/wiki/Kris_Kristofferson "Kris Kristofferson"), [Levon Helm](/wiki/Levon_Helm "Levon Helm"), [Bobby and Shirley Womack](/wiki/Bobby_Womack "Bobby Womack"), and [John Prine](/wiki/John_Prine "John Prine") "alongside a half-dozen original compositions."[68]
  * The group performs "[Back Home Again](/wiki/Back_Home_Again_\(song\) "Back Home Again \(song\)")" (track 6) on _[The Music Is You: A Tribute to John Denver](/wiki/The_Music_Is_You:_A_Tribute_to_John_Denver "The Music Is You: A Tribute to John Denver")_ (2013) on ATO Records, an album spotlighting "Denver's folky, sentimental songs done by popular and generally fashionable artists", including [My Morning Jacket](/wiki/My_Morning_Jacket "My Morning Jacket"), [Brandi Carlile](/wiki/Brandi_Carlile "Brandi Carlile"), Edward Sharpe & the Magnetic Zeros, Dave Matthews, [Lucinda Williams](/wiki/Lucinda_Williams "Lucinda Williams"), and [Josh Ritter](/wiki/Josh_Ritter "Josh Ritter").[69]

###
Solo[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Solo")]

  * In 2007, Gill Landry released a solo album titled _[The Ballad of Lawless Soirez](/wiki/The_Ballad_of_Lawless_Soirez "The Ballad of Lawless Soirez")_ on Nettwerk.[r 8]
  * In Spring/Summer of 2010, Landry released his second solo album titled _[Piety& Desire](/w/index.php?title=Piety_%26_Desire&action=edit&redlink=1 "Piety & Desire \(page does not exist\)")_, which features the [Felice Brothers](/wiki/Felice_Brothers "Felice Brothers"), [Brandi Carlile](/wiki/Brandi_Carlile "Brandi Carlile"), [Jolie Holland](/wiki/Jolie_Holland "Jolie Holland"), Ketch Secor, and Samantha Parton (of the [Be Good Tanyas](/wiki/Be_Good_Tanyas "Be Good Tanyas")).[r 9]
  * On March 3, 2015 Landry released a self-titled album through ATO Records, his third solo effort.[70]

##
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Old_Crow_Medicine_Show&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** A "thirty-year-old friend who had actually grown up playing old-time music, lived in an unheated room off the kitchen" at Dickerson Pike, where the group first lived in Nashville, and "occasionally played with the band" including their [Opry](/wiki/Grand_Ole_Opry "Grand Ole Opry") debut.[1]
  2. **Jump up ^** A "young folksy kind of jam element acoustic band that was really popular in the southern tier region of New York State. ." as Secor describes it. Watson "was playing shows statewide by the time he was sixteen" with "this group that had some [congas](/wiki/Conga "Conga") and some [clawhammer banjo](/wiki/Clawhammer "Clawhammer") . ."[19]:7
  3. **Jump up ^** "Ithaca is known far and wide as a hotbed of what's called old-time music," says [Pete "Dr. Banjo" Wernick](/wiki/Pete_Wernick "Pete Wernick"). Adds Mac Benford: "Ithaca for 40 years has been a center of old time music, nationally."[24]
  4. **Jump up ^** Secor recounts: "In the year 2000, his daughter heard us play outside of his favorite restaurant, the Boone Drug. Doc had something he liked on the menu at the Drug, so he was often there."[i 2]
  5. **Jump up ^** Founded in 1988 in memory of Doc's son Eddy Merle Watson, who died in a farm [tractor](/wiki/Tractor "Tractor") accident in 1985, as a [fundraiser](/wiki/Fundraising "Fundraising") for [Wilkes Community College](/wiki/Wilkes_Community_College "Wilkes Community College") and to celebrate "traditional plus" music.[w 6][27]
  6. **Jump up ^** when Ben Gould "had a baby, and couldn't swing it down south", according to Secor.[19]:7
  7. **Jump up ^** They first "occupied an inexpensive two-story house on a dead-end peninsula squeezed on three sides by highways, where the drone of passing cars was constant" on Dickerson Pike in E. Nashville "a thoroughfare best known for its whoring, drugging ways."[1][30]
  8. **Jump up ^** They would soon sign with Norm Parenteau, a Nashville agent who worked with Gillian Welch and Alison Krauss.[1]
  9. **Jump up ^** According to Fuqua, who wrote the song at 18: "The song is loosely based off [Mance Lipscomb](/wiki/Mance_Lipscomb "Mance Lipscomb"), a blues singer and [sharecropper](/wiki/Sharecropper "Sharecropper") from [Navasota County](/wiki/Navasota_County,_Texas "Navasota County, Texas"), and the rivers I remember as a child living in [East Texas](/wiki/East_Texas "East Texas"). He was a big influence on me."[i 6][w 7]
  10. **Jump up ^** Written when Secor was 17, adding verses to a Bob Dylan chorus, the song appeared earlier on the self-produced _Troubles Up and Down the Road_ (2001).[w 7][33][w 8]
  11. **Jump up ^** Secor reflects: "You can't always stay the same forever . . As much as it changed us to go through the break up with Will, it was tempered by the rejoining of Critter and now Corey Younts."[40]
  12. **Jump up ^** Left to pursue a solo career.[42]
